Description: Carved bone horse-head handle; inside hollowed out; pierced by two longitudinal holes, one through the nose and one at the end.
Curator's comments: Possibly Ptolemaic rather than Parthian: more parallels known from Roman Egypt, for instance in the Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge (inv. no E.12.1971, presented by the Egypt Exploration Society, from Saqqara) and the Royal Ontario Museum (inv. no 979.61.2). Others have passed through the art market (e.g., Dorotheum, 6th December 1997, lot 65; Sotheby's New York, 'Antiquities', 6 December 2012, lot 58).
Bibliographic references: Simpson 1997a / Bone, ivory, and shell: Artifacts of the Persian through Roman periods (p.344) (illustrated with comments on p.345)
Barnett & Davies 1975a / A catalogue of Nimrud ivories with other examples of Ancient Near Eastern Ivories (Suppl.75)
Curtis & Tallis 2012 / The Horse from Arabia to Ascot (125)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2012 24 May-30 Sep, BM, 'The horse: from Arabia to Royal Ascot' 2010 29 May-15 Oct, USA, Kentucky Horse Park, 'A Gift from the Desert' 1995-2005 17 Nov-Dec, BM, G52/IRAN/13/19 1994 BM, G49/Iran 1975-ca 1990 Jul-, BM, Iranian Room [IR], case ?, no. 24
